title: Is it possible for two objects to be at rest after a collision if one of them is at rest before the collision? - Quora

response.answer_text: I keep re-reading this question to better understand it. Assuming that M1 and M2 are equal or close to equal in mass: M1 and M2 would need to be different densities through out. Maybe like an M&M where the candy coating is tougher than the middle. (Both would need the harder exterior) The speed at which they collided would have to be fairly slow. (Slower than gravity would allow) And then, they would “bounce” off each other with such little energy that they only get so far apart before gravity gets a complete hold and keeps them in a stable orbit around each other. So therefore, no, neither could ever be at rest, especially since there was a collision to begin with. If M1 were substantially larger than M2, then M2 would need to be structurally superior than M1 even with its lower mass. And then, both would end up in orbit around each other even though it would appear that M1 was at rest. (nothing is truly ever at rest) So no, you couldn’t get just one mass to be at rest and you’d have an even harder time to get both to be at rest.

Yes, but that momentum and energy needs to go somewhere. So imagine a wall struck by a car. The car and wall take damage but the wall and car are stopped. The reason is because the wall transfers the momentum to the air behind it and the ground it is on. As well, the sound and heat of the collision causes the energy to dissipate. It isn't destroyed, but changed to a less usable form (we call this entropy.)

If two objects collide, the total momentum after the collision must equal the total momentum before the collision. If one object is at rest, the total momentum of the system before the collision is the momentum of the moving object. If both objects are at rest afterwards, the total momentum is zero. This is not possible. Mathematically:  cannot be true if p is non-zero. Lots of wrong answers to this one.

Sure, as long as there’s so much deformation that they stick together. I’m assuming, of course, that you’re talking about “at rest” relative to each other and not some unmentioned third object. For a purely elastic collision, though, no, the momenta between them before the collision will be shared between them after it.

If all of the energy of the two objects colliding is expended within the objects (inelastic deformation), or imparted somewhere else (a third object?) Then yes they can both be at rest. Otherwise one will move

This question doesn't really make sense. What are they at rest relative to? If only one is at rest then it can't be at rest relative to the other. Being at rest requires a reference frame which moves in uniform with the other object. So, both of them can be at rest relative to something. Whether that something is the same thing depends on the collision.
Yes, a good example is: Newton's cradle - Wikipedia A ball hits a row of identical balls that are at rest and comes to rest with all the balls except the last one.
Not theoretically perfectly static, but very close if the masses are extremely different in magnitudes.
Sure. The chances are incredibly small but completely possible.
